title: Bypass Tracking Blocker Protection Using Slashes Without Protocol On The Image Source.

profile.name: Basecamp
profile.about: Basecamp is the leading online project manager and the birthplace of Ruby on Rails.

vulnerability_information:
## Summary: - Some Way Has Been Discovered To Bypass Image Rewriting On HeyMail Using Slashes Without Protocol `\/\www.evil.com` That Allows Bypassing Tracking Blocker And Collect Users Information Via Emails. ## Description: - While Searching I Found That The Image Rewriting Function On Heymail Could Be Bypass Using Slashes Since It Seems To Be Depending On A Blacklist. In The Normal Users Are Able To Request External URLs From Images, JS Imports , CSS Imports, ..etc Using Two Slashes Before The Domain. In This Case Users Wasn't Able To Do That Since When The Image Rewriting Function Is Detecting Two Slashes On The First Two Chars Of The URL Source It Creates An External URL For It On gopher.hey.com. But Due To Some Lack On This Validation Users Are Able To Bypass The Images Rewriting By Inserting Another Slash Between The Two Slashes That Won't Change The URL. In This Case I Used `\/\`. - I Created A Simple Image Tag With This Payload: `` And I Sended It Into My Testing HeyMail Email And I Got That The Web Browser Sent A GET Request Into `www.evil.com` Directly. {F1104089} ## Proof Of Concept: - There Isn't Much Stuff Here. But, Here's A Simple Exploit HTML Code You Can Use To Trigger This Issue. ```html

Hello World

Open The Network Tab

``` Best Regards. ## Impact Bypassing Image Rewriting Function Witch Allows Trackers To Collect Users IPs Using Images.
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:

  • Some Way Has Been Discovered To Bypass Image Rewriting On HeyMail Using Slashes Without Protocol \/\www.evil.com That Allows Bypassing Tracking Blocker And Collect Users Information Via Emails.

Description:

  • While Searching I Found That The Image Rewriting Function On Heymail Could Be Bypass Using Slashes Since It Seems To Be Depending On A Blacklist. In The Normal Users Are Able To Request External URLs From Images, JS Imports , CSS Imports, ..etc Using Two Slashes Before The Domain. In This Case Users Wasn't Able To Do That Since When The Image Rewriting Function Is Detecting Two Slashes On The First Two Chars Of The URL Source It Creates An External URL For It On gopher.hey.com. But Due To Some Lack On This Validation Users Are Able To Bypass The Images Rewriting By Inserting Another Slash Between The Two Slashes That Won't Change The URL. In This Case I Used \/\.

  • I Created A Simple Image Tag With This Payload: <img src="\/\www.evil.com"> And I Sended It Into My Testing HeyMail Email And I Got That The Web Browser Sent A GET Request Into www.evil.com Directly.

Proof Of Concept:

  • There Isn't Much Stuff Here. But, Here's A Simple Exploit HTML Code You Can Use To Trigger This Issue.
<h1>Hello World</h1>
<img src="\/\www.evil.com"  >
<h3>Open The Network Tab</h3>

Best Regards.

Impact

Bypassing Image Rewriting Function Witch Allows Trackers To Collect Users IPs Using Images.

activities.message: Hi @demonia, How are you delivering that email to your HEY account? I have tried a couple of methods for delivering an HTML email with `` I always get this in HEY: ```html ``` I'd appreciate if you can detail the steps. I've checked our image-rewriting code and I think you are onto something here, but I'd like to fully reproduce the vulnerability. Thanks
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @demonia,

How are you delivering that email to your HEY account?

I have tried a couple of methods for delivering an HTML email with <img src="\/\www.evil.com" > I always get this in HEY:

<action-text-attachment content-type="image" url="\/\www.evil.com" previewable="true"></action-text-attachment>

I'd appreciate if you can detail the steps. I've checked our image-rewriting code and I think you are onto something here, but I'd like to fully reproduce the vulnerability.

Thanks

I just created another account. and i sent the same payload into it. this issue seems to be fired only from my side. i don't really know why but in my side the email is loading this image. but in the other side on the user that i sent the email to it don't.

you seems to be right. i don't really know what's the situation here but i will try to go deeper and find a way to trigger it on the other user. and again sorry for the missing information.

activities.message: Hey Jorge. I have a good news, i was able to bypass this protection on only 10 mintues! i'm so confused but here's the new payload and let me explain some stuff: `` now if you give img take two sources it will take the first one. and it won't apply the second one. but in the srcset even if i added src at the first. srcset is the source that will work in this case. so due to the protection here that converts the image into something doesn't request the image. i allowed the rewrite function to set a source here so it could send a clear img tag on the source. i gived it another src on the tag with a valid url so it will get replaced but the real url here on srcset will be applied
activities.markdown_message:
Hey Jorge. I have a good news, i was able to bypass this protection on only 10 mintues! i'm so confused but here's the new payload and let me explain some stuff: <img srcset="/\/www.evil.com" src="https://www.evil.com/"/></img>

now if you give img take two sources it will take the first one. and it won't apply the second one. but in the srcset even if i added src at the first. srcset is the source that will work in this case.

so due to the protection here that converts the image into something doesn't request the image. i allowed the rewrite function to set a source here so it could send a clear img tag on the source. i gived it another src on the tag with a valid url so it will get replaced but the real url here on srcset will be applied

activities.message:
Fantastic work @demonia. There is indeed a difference in the processing we do for external and internal emails. It was pretty amazing that you quickly found how to make it work for external emails too. I could easily reproduce the vulnerability now.

You killed it with your reports today 🙏! Thanks a lot. Keep them coming :)
activities.markdown_message:
Fantastic work @demonia. There is indeed a difference in the processing we do for external and internal emails. It was pretty amazing that you quickly found how to make it work for external emails too. I could easily reproduce the vulnerability now.

You killed it with your reports today 🙏! Thanks a lot. Keep them coming :)

activities.message: @demonia I saw the failing www.evil.com in the network panel and I thought it was hitting www.evil.com but it was actually hitting our proxy server (see attached capture). Can you reproduce the issue where your image hits www.evil.com? It's ok regarding the bounty, that was my mistake, but I'd love to know if you can reproduce.
activities.markdown_message: @demonia I saw the failing www.evil.com in the network panel and I thought it was hitting www.evil.com but it was actually hitting our proxy server (see attached capture). Can you reproduce the issue where your image hits www.evil.com? It's ok regarding the bounty, that was my mistake, but I'd love to know if you can reproduce.

activities.message: Heymail service seems to be having some kind of protection for external emails. the bypass i got at the first `/\/` doesn't really work for external emails. that's why it didn't work. it should but until finding another bypass that works for external ones. this attack could only be performed from hey users itself. i'm sorry for what happened i should test the external urls too it's all my mistake here. and i'm so sorry for that. i will try to get a bypass for this case tonight.
activities.markdown_message: Heymail service seems to be having some kind of protection for external emails. the bypass i got at the first /\/ doesn't really work for external emails. that's why it didn't work. it should but until finding another bypass that works for external ones. this attack could only be performed from hey users itself. i'm sorry for what happened i should test the external urls too it's all my mistake here. and i'm so sorry for that. i will try to get a bypass for this case tonight.

activities.message:
@demonia I could confirm the vulnerability is valid and it's working as you reported. I was doing my tests with different systems but I was using gmail as the carrier, and it was just stripping out the `srcset` attribute. I tried with a raw HTML sent with our own relay and it worked fine. 

It didn't make sense that it worked from another HEY account but not from an external service. Both are going through the same pipeline (there is a difference though if you use the same account).

So at the end the report was totally valid 👍

Thanks for the effort to clarify things here.
activities.markdown_message:
@demonia I could confirm the vulnerability is valid and it's working as you reported. I was doing my tests with different systems but I was using gmail as the carrier, and it was just stripping out the srcset attribute. I tried with a raw HTML sent with our own relay and it worked fine.

It didn't make sense that it worked from another HEY account but not from an external service. Both are going through the same pipeline (there is a difference though if you use the same account).

So at the end the report was totally valid 👍

Thanks for the effort to clarify things here.

activities.message: Oh, i was using gmail too, that's why it didn't work. BTW thanks for your response and the bounty. i learned alot from this report.
activities.markdown_message: Oh, i was using gmail too, that's why it didn't work. BTW thanks for your response and the bounty. i learned alot from this report.

activities.message: We deployed a change to our CSP that prevents loading images from uncontrolled sources. We'd appreciate if you can confirm you can't reproduce the vulnerability anymore. Thanks
activities.markdown_message: We deployed a change to our CSP that prevents loading images from uncontrolled sources. We'd appreciate if you can confirm you can't reproduce the vulnerability anymore. Thanks

activities.message: Yeah the issue seems to be fixed with me. the CSP is blocking the image loading in this case. it's fine for me with the disclosure here. have a great day!
